title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.19 Part 2 | 16-08-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: The meaning of this verse is, the learned Brahmanas said, O son of Pritha, this child shall be exactly like King Ikshwaku, the son of Manu, in maintaining all those who are born.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam and explains that the child Pariksit will be like King Ikshwaku in maintaining those who are born and like Rama in being true to his promise.

segments.key_quote: This body is actually a prison house.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that taking birth in the material world is like imprisonment, where the body imposes limitations on the spirit soul, and saintly kings provide protection to all living beings to fulfill their duties and terms of imprisonment.
The speaker emphasizes the importance of protecting all living beings, including cows and trees, and criticizes the modern tendency to prioritize only human beings.

segments.key_quote: From the scriptures we understand there are different varieties of bodies.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that all living beings, including animals and trees, have a spirit soul and a right to live, and those who violate this right will be punished by the laws of nature.

segments.key_quote: It's only in the Vedic literature you find the facts explained about Who am I?
segments.summary: The speaker highlights the importance of Vedic literature in understanding the nature of all creatures and emphasizes that every living being has feelings that originate from the spirit soul within the body.

segments.key_quote: If I give pain to somebody else, I'll be punished by the laws of nature that I also have to suffer similar pain in future.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of a child who cannot express their pain, the speaker explains that all living beings feel pain, even if they cannot express it, and inflicting pain on others will result in punishment according to the laws of nature.

The speaker concludes by emphasizing the philosophy of 'live and let live' taught in Vedic literature and explains how knowledge is passed down through disciplic succession, using the example of Krishna teaching the Bhagavad Gita to the Sun God, who then taught it to his son Manu, and then to Ikshvaku.
